Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Collaborative: Data Driven Post-Disaster Waste and Debris Volume Predictions using Smartphone Photogrammetry App and Unmanned Aerial Vehicles

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this proposal is to leverage photogrammetry from smart phones and unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) to automate the quantification of waste debris. In the aftermath of Hurricane Harvey and associated rainfall-induced flooding, a significant volume of waste and debris will be generated, especially in urban areas such as Houston and Beaumont, Texas. The management of post-disaster debris is an important issue faced by local and federal authorities: it contributes a significant portion of disaster management costs, can generate several times the annual waste generation rates of the affected community, and leads to higher expenditures due to error prone initial debris estimations. The current process to predict debris volume is inaccurate and inefficient, as it utilizes qualitative data from visual observation. The results of this study will improve the calibration of the flood debris estimation models by measuring debris generation due to Hurricane Harvey. This will aid in decision-making tools that ultimately will result in faster and more cost-effective debris management operations for future rainfall, tropical storm, and hurricane-induced flood events that continue to impact the Gulf, the US, and elsewhere around the world.

This RAPID project addresses the lack of post-disaster debris volume dataset by collecting ephemeral data through an automated smartphone photogrammetric app and UAV in Beaumont and other affected regions in Texas, and making the data available through open-source cyber-infrastructure databases. Debris volumes will be quantified by exploring the use of smartphones to automate the quantification of waste debris. In particular, smart phone images captured by the monitor, resident, or local government agency can be processed and scaled to develop a 3-D rendition and an estimate of waste volumes. These estimations will be validated using an unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) photogrammetry surveys and which in turn can be converted using volumetric studies as well as other available debris volumes documented by monitoring companies. If successful, smartphones and UAVs can be quickly used in future natural disasters to analyze and characterize the digital images and then accurately quantify waste debris volumes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Harvey was the most significant tropical cyclone rainfall event in United States history. These rains caused catastrophic flooding in Harris and Galveston counties, with 9 out of the 19 official river gauges in Harris County (which includes the city of Houston) recording all-time high flood stages. In particular, NOAA completed an analysis of annual exceedance probabilities for southeastern Texas after Harvey and concluded that a large portion of that area experienced a flood with less than a 1-in-1000 (0.1%) chance of occurring in any given year (e.g., a 1000-year or greater flood). Due to recent rainfall-induced flooding, significant volumes of waste debris were generated in Louisiana (Lake Charles) and Texas (Houston, Beaumont, Galveston).

The management of post-disaster debris is an important issue faced by local and federal authorities because it contributes an estimated 25% to disaster management costs, can generate 5 to 15 times the annual waste generation rates of the affected community, and specifically leads to the most federal funding being lost due to mismanagement. To reduce the risks of fraud or mismanagement, FEMA reimburses consulting companies for the costs of professional debris monitoring services. These companies deploy a debris management system to electronically collect, store, and manage debris project data and information. However, substantial inefficiencies still exist in waste debris removal. For example, the collection and disposal procedures involve the monitoring company to scan the truck barcode, tag the location, and identify the waste type. A ticket is provided to the truck driver, who transports the waste to a landfill. The monitoring company has another individual in a tower at the landfill who collects the ticket, peers into the truck bed, and writes the percent of truck bed filled. This process is based on visual observation and purely qualitative.

This research attempted the usage of unmanned aerial vehicles and smartphone based photogrammetry to estimate debris volume collected at the curbside in a quick, safe, and accurate manner. These studies were done at eight debris sites along the city streets. The UAV-CRP technology offers the capability to collect waste debris volumes data with less boots on the ground, which is a necessity for agencies managing tasks immediately after a disaster. The orthomosaics and digital elevation models obtained from the aerial technology helped in calculating the volume of debris in a quick manner.

The smartphone based debris volume predictions were found to be different than the UAV based debris volume predictions. However, this discrepancy is likely attributed to insufficient markers in the smart phone photos to delineate actual dimensions. Research teams also collected the printed landfill tickets, which were subsequently digitized into a database to better understand the logistics of waste generation, collection, and disposal. Overall, the UAV based debris volume predictions appear to be sound and hence can be used for debris estimation at hazard events.
